reasoning: [Specific Program Not Verified] Paper mentions 'Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA)' but search could not confirm this as graduation program: Perplexity search result: MGNREGA is not a graduation program per the standard definition used in poverty research: graduation programs (like BRAC's or IPA's models) are multi-component interventions for the ultra-poor which generally include asset transfers, cash stipends, coaching, and financial inclusion, specifically targeting sustainable exit from extreme poverty with lasting livelihood change[4][9]. MGNREGA is a wage employment guarantee scheme entitling rural households up to 100 days of paid manual work per year, based on self-selection, not household targeting for ultra-poor or intensive accompaniment[3][5][6]. The scheme provides a cash component in the form of wages for labor[2][5], and importantly, it funds local infrastructure development through participants' work, resulting in productive assets such as roads, ponds, check dams, irrigation facilities, and more, which are community assetsâ€”not individualized household transfers[2][3]. Several sources note MGNREGA's role in poverty reduction, income stability, and asset creation (community assets), but its structure and objectives differ from the graduation approach; it is primarily an employment guarantee program for poor and vulnerable rural households, not an integrated ultra-poor graduation program[3][5][1][6]. | Graduation: NO, Cash: YES, Assets: YES | Confidence: HIGH | Sources: https://www.giz.de/en/downloads/Working%20Paper%20-%20An%20Introduction%20to%20MGNREGA%20Innovations%20and%20their%20Potential%20for%20India-Africa%20Linkages.pdf, https://www.nilerd.ac.in/writereaddata/UploadFile/RaviKumarGuptaandVaibhavKantMishra.pdf, https://ihds.umd.edu/system/files/2021-03/MGNREGA%20Report%20Complete2015-08-08.pdf
verified_program_name: Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA)
